div.head: Boundaries Placed between Caesarea ad Libanum and the Gigarteni of the Vicus Sidoniorum

p.seg: This fragmentary inscribed boundary marker attests to an authoritative demarcation between two peoples in the southern part of Roman Syria.

div.p: The demarcation was ordered (fines positit ... iussu ...) by an individual whose name and titulature have been erased from the inscription. Burton 2000 no. 52 assumes he was a procurator, but most editors assume he was an imperial legate (i.e., the provincial governor of Syria). The demarcation was actually carried out by an individual whose name has been lost through damage to the stone, presumably a centurion or other military figure, possibly a surveyor.

div.ab:
Fines positi inter
Caesarenses ad
Libanum et Gigarte
nos de vico Sidonior(um)
iussu [[[--- leg(ati)? Aug(usti)?]]] pro [pr(aetore)?]
per Dom[itium? ---]
-----

div.p: Boundaries placed between the Caesarenses ad Libanum and the Gigarteni de vicus Sidoniorum, by order of , through Dom(itius ?) ...
